<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/mirai-variant-iz1h9';
	}
</script>

	<title>Old Wine in the New Bottle: Mirai Variant Targets Multiple IoT Devices</title>
	<meta name="description" content="We analyze Mirai variant IZ1H9, which targets IoT devices. Our overview includes campaigns observed, botnet configuration and vulnerabilities exploited." />
	<link rel="canonical" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/mirai-variant-iz1h9/" />

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/vulnerabilities/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Chao Lei"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Zhibin Zhang"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Cecilia Hu"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>

<meta name="post_tags" content="CVE-2023-26801,CVE-2023-26802,CVE-2023-27076,IoT,IZ1H9,Mirai variant"/>
<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/Unit42-blog-2by1-characters-r4d1-2020_New-mirai-variant-green.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Old Wine in the New Bottle: Mirai Variant Targets Multiple IoT Devices","name":"Old Wine in the New Bottle: Mirai Variant Targets Multiple IoT Devices","description":"We analyze Mirai variant IZ1H9, which targets IoT devices. Our overview includes campaigns observed, botnet configuration and vulnerabilities exploited.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/mirai-variant-iz1h9\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/mirai-variant-iz1h9\/","datePublished":"May 25, 2023","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nOn April 10, Unit 42 researchers observed a Mirai variant called IZ1H9, which used several vulnerabilities to spread itself. The threat actors use the following vulnerabilities to target exposed servers and networking devices running Linux:\r\n\r\n \tCVE-2023-27076: Tenda G103 command injection vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2023-26801: LB-Link command injection vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2023-26802: DCN DCBI-Netlog-LAB remote code execution vulnerability\r\n \tZyxel remote code execution vulnerability\r\n\r\nCompromised devices can be fully controlled by attackers and become a part of the botnet. Those devices can be used to conduct further attacks, such as distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks Next Generation Firewall customers receive protections through Cloud-Delivered Security Services such as IoT Security, Advanced Threat Prevention, WildFire and Advanced URL Filtering, which can help detect and block the exploit traffic and malware.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nMirai variant, IoT\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCampaign Overview\r\nSince November 2021, Unit 42 researchers have observed multiple campaigns using the Mirai IZ1H9 variant. Based on our analysis, we believe that these campaigns were operated by the same threat actor for the following reasons:\r\n\r\n \tThe malware shell script downloaders used in both campaigns are almost identical.\r\n \tThe botnet samples use the same XOR decryption key: 0xBAADF00D\r\n \tThe botnet client samples use almost identical functions.\r\n \tBotnet client samples among those campaigns share the same infrastructure.\r\n\r\nOn April 10, 2023, Unit 42 researchers observed some abnormal traffic from our threat hunting system. This threat group tried to download and execute a shell script downloader lb.sh from IP 163.123.143[.]126.\r\n\r\nIf executed, the shell script downloader would first delete logs to hide its tracks. Then the following bot clients would be downloaded and executed, to accommodate different Linux architectures:\r\n\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.x86\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.mips\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.mpsl\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.arm4\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.arm5\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.arm6\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.arm7\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.ppc\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.m68k\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.sh4\r\n \thxxp:\/\/163.123.143[.]126\/bins\/dark.86_64\r\n\r\nIn the last step, the shell script downloader would block network connection from several ports including SSH, telnet and HTTP. It did so by modifying the device\u2019s iptable rules, so that the victim wouldn\u2019t be able to connect and recover the compromised device remotely, as depicted in Figure 1.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128225\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"398\"] Figure 1. Iptable modification.[\/caption]\r\nThreat Group Analysis\r\nUnit 42 researchers conducted analysis on the downloaded botnet client samples and found two URLs hosting more shell script downloaders:\r\n\r\n \thxxp:\/\/2.56.59[.]215\/i.sh\r\n \thxxp:\/\/212.192.241[.]72\/lolol.sh\r\n\r\nFigure 2 is a diagram illustrating the campaign overview.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128227\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. Campaign overview diagram.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe shell script downloader from 2.56.59[.]215 would download botnet clients from hxxp:\/\/2.56.59[.]215\/bins\/. Those botnet client samples would contact a command and control (C2) server at 195.133.40[.]141 where there were URLs in the malware samples that hosted two shell scripts:\r\n\r\n \thxxp:\/\/31.210.20[.]100\/lolol[.]sh\r\n \thxxp:\/\/212.192.241[.]72\/lolol[.]sh\r\n\r\nThe shell script downloader from 212.192.241[.]72 would download botnet clients from hxxp:\/\/212.192.241[.]87\/bins\/, and those botnet client samples would contact the C2 domain dotheneedfull[.]club.\r\nMalware Analysis\r\nBased on behavior and patterns Unit 42 researchers observed during the analysis of the downloaded samples, we believe that they are a variant of the Mirai botnet called IZ1H9.\r\n\r\nDiscovered in August 2018, IZ1H9 is one of the most active Mirai variants. Just like the original Mirai, the IZ1H9 botnet client first checks the network portion of the infected device\u2019s IP address. The client avoids execution for a list of IP blocks, including government networks, internet providers and large tech companies.\r\n\r\nThe botnet client makes its presence visible by printing the word \u201cDarknet\u201d to the console. The malware also contains a function that ensures the device is running only one instance of this malware. If a botnet process already exists, the botnet client will terminate the current process and start a new one, as depicted in Figure 3.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128229\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"663\"] Figure 3. IZ1H9 ensures there is only a single instance of execution.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe botnet client also contains a list of process names belonging to other Mirai variants and other botnet malware families. The malware checks the running process names on the infected host to terminate them.\r\n\r\nThe IZ1H9 variant tries to connect to a hard-coded C2 address: 193.47.61[.]75, as shown in Figure 4.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128231\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"333\"] Figure 4. IZ1H9 malware C2 address.[\/caption]\r\nBotnet Client Configuration String Decryption\r\nFor botnet client configuration strings, the IZ1H9 variant will first initialize an encrypted string table. It will then retrieve the encrypted strings through an index (as shown in Figures 5 and 6).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128233\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"407\"] Figure 5. Initializing the encrypted string table.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128235\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"734\"] Figure 6. IZ1H9 retrieving strings.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe IZ1H9 variant uses a table key during the string decryption process: 0xBAADF00D. For each encrypted character, the malware performs XOR decryption with the following bytewise operations:\r\ncipher_char ^ 0xBA ^ 0xAD ^ 0xF0 ^ 0x0D = plain_char\r\nAccording to the logic behind XOR operation, the configuration string key equals to\r\n0xBA ^ 0xAD ^ 0xF0 ^ 0x0D = 0xEA\r\n\r\nIZ1H9 Sample Spreading Through HTTP, SSH and Telnet Protocol\r\nFor SSH and telnet channels, IZ1H9 inherits the most significant feature from the original Mirai source code: a data section with embedded default login credentials for scanner and brute-force purposes.\r\n\r\nThe original Mirai and IZ1H9 also both encrypt their login credentials with a 1 byte XOR key. The keys vary in different versions, but this variant uses 0x54, as shown in Figure 7.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128237\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"387\"] Figure 7. IZ1H9 variant credentials XOR decryption.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis IZ1H9 variant initializes the table of nearly 100 pairs of telnet\/SSH login credentials in the scanner function. It then spreads through brute forcing network devices\u2019 weak username and password combinations.\r\n\r\nFor the HTTP channel, IZ1H9 uses four remote code execution vulnerabilities to get access to the vulnerable devices, and it executes the shellcode script downloader shown in Figure 8.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128239\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 8. Exploit scanner function.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nNotice that in the Tenda vulnerability exploit function, the payload downloads tenda.sh from the malware host server but executes netlog.sh, as shown in Figure 9. In this case, the exploit will not work.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128241\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"805\"] Figure 9: Malware executes wrong downloader.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe malware will initialize all DDoS attack functions before the botnet client establishes a connection with the C2 server. According to the Mirai source code, the malware developer will define the attack method and assign a command code to represent the attack method, as depicted in Figure 10.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128243\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"541\"] Figure 10. Mirai attack method definition.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIn this IZ1H9 sample, the threat actor defines a set of attack methods, shown in Table 1.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCommand\u00a0\r\nAttack Method\r\nDescription\r\n\r\n\r\n0\r\nattack_method_tcpsyn\r\nTCP SYN flooding attack\r\n\r\n\r\n1\r\nattack_method_tcpack\r\nTCP ACK flooding attack\r\n\r\n\r\n2\r\nattack_method_tcpusyn\r\nTCP URG-SYN flooding attack\r\n\r\n\r\n3\r\nattack_method_tcpall\r\nTCP DDoS with all options set\r\n\r\n\r\n4\r\nattack_method_tcpfrag\r\nTCP fragmentation attack\r\n\r\n\r\n5\r\nattack_method_asyn\r\nTCP SYN-ACK flooding attack\r\n\r\n\r\n6\r\nattack_method_udpgame\r\nUDP attack targets online gaming servers\r\n\r\n\r\n7\r\nattack_method_udpplain\r\nUDP flooding with fewer options\r\n\r\n\r\n8\r\nattack_method_greip\r\nGRE IP flooding attack\r\n\r\n\r\n9\r\nattack_method_std\r\nSTD flooding attack\r\n\r\n\r\n10\r\nattack_method_udpdns\r\nDNS flooding attack\r\n\r\n\r\n11\r\nattack_method_udpgeneric\r\nUDP flooding attack\r\n\r\n\r\n12\r\nattack_app_http\r\nHTTP flooding attack\r\n\r\n\r\n13\r\nattack_method_dnsamp\r\nDNS amplification attack\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. IZ1H9 attack method.\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nIoT devices have always been a lucrative target for threat actors, and remote code execution attacks continue to be the most common and most concerning threats affecting IoT devices and linux servers. Exposed vulnerable devices could lead to serious threats.\r\n\r\nThe vulnerabilities used by this threat are less complex, but this does not decrease their impact, since they could still lead to remote code execution. Once the attacker gains control of a vulnerable device, they can include the newly compromised devices in their botnet. This allows them to conduct further attacks such as DDoS.\r\n\r\nTo combat this threat, it is highly recommended that patches and updates are applied when possible.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers receive protection from the vulnerabilities and malware discussed above through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tNext Generation Firewall with a Threat Prevention security subscription can help block the attacks with Best Practices via Threat Prevention signatures: 93386, 93718, 93721, 93722.\r\n \tAdvanced Threat Prevention provides inline machine learning that can detect vulnerability exploits in real time.\r\n \tWildFire can help stop the malware with static signature detections.\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and DNS Security are able to block the C2 domain and malware-hosting URLs.\r\n \tThe Palo Alto Networks IoT Security platform can leverage network traffic information to identify the vendor, model and firmware version of a device, and it can identify specific devices that are vulnerable to particular CVEs.\r\n \tIn addition, IoT Security has inbuilt machine learning-based anomaly detection that can alert the customer if a device exhibits nontypical behavior such as the sudden appearance of traffic from a new source, an unusually high number of connections, or an inexplicable surge of certain attributes typically appearing in IoT application payloads.\r\n\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nArtifacts\r\nShell Script Downloader\r\n\r\n \t692a5d099e37cd94923ea2b2014d79e6e613fb061a985069736dd3d55d4330c4\r\n \te0b1c324298eeccd54ffc2ff48288ec51fbec44f5f82229537508785a9bda6de\r\n \t931800d4f84bda7c0368c915dfd27721d63ed0ce6a9bc9f13e1417d4c2fe88f3\r\n \t64a350a33757f6631dc375632de191967ae59c876b4718a087e299bd54f23844\r\n\r\nMirai Variant Sample\r\n\r\n \t23190d722ba3fe97d859bd9b086ff33a14ae9aecfc8a2c3427623f93de3d3b14\r\n \t00b151ff78a492b5eae0c8d3c769857f171f8424cf36c3b2505f7d7889109599\r\n \t212b1af9fd1142d86b61956ac1198623f9017153153cfc20bfeab6a9fd44004a\r\n \t38406b2effd9fc37ce41ee914fda798de9c9b0e239a0cc94b1464dc2a9984fe9\r\n \t21185d9b7344edcd8d9c4af174e468c38cb3b061e6bd6bd64a4be9bd3fa27ff5\r\n \t65a46cd29dad935d067a4289445d2efb2710d44d789bf1bf0efb29f94d20e531\r\n \t06ef6c76e481d25aa09b3b15959d702be29c22d63bd35524766397e3d36d0d2e\r\n \t7bfb02c563ae266e81ba94a745ea7017f12010d5491708d748296332f26f04f5\r\n \t1e29f364f502b313f01f28f1ae85bf27114fae5eede6550809fe5bca58f59174\r\n\r\nInfrastructure\r\nMalware C2\r\n\r\n \t193.47.61[.]75\r\n \t195.133.40[.]141\r\n \tdotheneedfull[.]club\r\n\r\nMalware Host\r\n\r\n \t163.123.143[.]126\r\n \t2.56.59[.]215\r\n \t212.192.241[.]72\r\n \t212.192.241[.]87\r\n \t31.210.20[.]100\r\n\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n \tMirai Variant V3G4 Targets IoT Devices - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tNew Mirai Variant Targeting Network Security Devices - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tMirai Variant MooBot Targeting D-Link Devices - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tNetwork Security Trends: August-October 2022 - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n\r\nAppendix\r\nCampaign-related vulnerability information is listed below:\r\n\r\nCVE-2023-27076: Tenda G103 Command Injection Vulnerability\r\n\r\nThis malicious traffic was first detected as a part of the IZ1H9 campaign on April 10, 2023. The command injection vulnerability is due to the failure to sanitize the value of the language parameter in the cgi-bin\/luci interface of Tenda G103.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128245\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"726\"] Figure 11. CVE-2023-27076 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2023-26801: LB-Link Command Injection Vulnerability\r\n\r\nWe captured this exploit traffic on April 10, 2023. The exploit targets a command injection vulnerability in the LB-Link wireless router\u2019s \/goform\/set_LimitClinet_cfg component, which does not successfully sanitize the user input in the time1, time2 and mac parameters. This leads to arbitrary command execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128247\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"657\"] Figure 12. CVE-2023-26801 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2023-26802: DCN DCBI-Netlog-LAB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nThe exploit was detected on April 10, 2023. The exploit works due to the Digital China Network DCBI-Netlog-LAB nsg_masq.cgi component failing to adequately sanitize the user-supplied input data, which leads to remote command execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128249\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"725\"] Figure 13. CVE-2023-26802 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nZyxel Remote Code Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nWe observed this exploit traffic on Dec. 16, 2022. The exploit targets the Zyxel router\u2019s \/bin\/zhttpd\/ component. If insufficient input validation is found, the attacker can exploit the vulnerability to launch a remote code execution attack.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_128251\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"528\"] Figure 14. Zyxel router exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nUpdated May 26, 2023, at 3:30 p.m. PT.","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/06\/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Chao Lei"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Zhibin Zhang"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Cecilia Hu"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />
<style id='co-authors-plus-coauthors-style-inline-css'>
.wp-block-co-authors-plus-coauthors.is-layout-flow [class*=wp-block-co-authors-plus]{display:inline}

</style>

<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-128221 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/trend-reports/" role="link" title="Trend Reports" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:hero:breadcrumb:Trend Reports">Trend Reports</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/vulnerabilities/" role="link" title="Vulnerabilities" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:hero:breadcrumb:Vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</a></li> </ul>

                  </ul>
                  
	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">
	<a href="#" role="link" title="Click here to share" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:share" class="">Share<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/down-arrow.svg" alt="Down arrow"></a><ul class="share-dropdown" role="menu">

				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="mailto:?subject=Old%20Wine%20in%20the%20New%20Bottle:%20Mirai%20Variant%20Targets%20Multiple%20IoT%20Devices&#038;body=Check%20out%20this%20article%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fmirai-variant-iz1h9%2F" role="link" title="Share in email" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:share:email"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-sms.svg" alt="Link Email"></a>

				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/mirai-variant-iz1h9/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-128221-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>On April 10, Unit 42 researchers observed a Mirai variant called IZ1H9, which used several vulnerabilities to spread itself. The threat actors use the following vulnerabilities to target exposed servers and networking devices running Linux:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-27076" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CVE-2023-27076</a>: Tenda G103 command injection vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-26801" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CVE-2023-26801</a>: LB-Link command injection vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-26802" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CVE-2023-26802</a>: DCN DCBI-Netlog-LAB remote code execution vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://www.zyxel.com/global/en/support/security-advisories/zyxel-security-advisory-for-remote-code-execution-and-denial-of-service-vulnerabilities-of-cpe" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Zyxel remote code execution vulnerability</a></li>
</ul>
<p>Compromised devices can be fully controlled by attackers and become a part of the botnet. Those devices can be used to conduct further attacks, such as distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next Generation Firewall</a> customers receive protections through <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloud-Delivered Security Services</a> such as <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/smart-devices-smarter-iot-security?utm_source=google-jg-amer-cdss&amp;utm_medium=paid_search&amp;utm_term=palo%20alto%20networks%20iot%20security&amp;utm_campaign=google-cdss-iot_security-amer-ca-awareness-en&amp;utm_content=gs-19633824690-151442986731-646705931499&amp;sfdcid=7014u000001hHCRAA2&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMI1Lm26OmS_QIVQUNyCh1G3gKWEAAYASAAEgJ3KvD_BwE" target="_blank" rel="noopener">IoT Security</a>, <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Threat Prevention</a>, <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a>, which can help detect and block the exploit traffic and malware.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/mirai-variant/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Mirai variant</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/iot/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">IoT</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-128221-_bb43emgsym4e"></a>Campaign Overview</h2>
<p>Since November 2021, Unit 42 researchers have observed multiple campaigns using the Mirai IZ1H9 variant. Based on our analysis, we believe that these campaigns were operated by the same threat actor for the following reasons:</p>
<ul>
<li>The malware shell script downloaders used in both campaigns are almost identical.</li>
<li>The botnet samples use the same XOR decryption key: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xBAADF00D</span></li>
<li>The botnet client samples use almost identical functions.</li>
<li>Botnet client samples among those campaigns share the same infrastructure.</li>
</ul>
<p>On April 10, 2023, Unit 42 researchers observed some abnormal traffic from our threat hunting system. This threat group tried to download and execute a shell script downloader <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">lb.sh</span> from IP <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">163.123.143[.]126</span>.</p>
<p>If executed, the shell script downloader would first delete logs to hide its tracks. Then the following bot clients would be downloaded and executed, to accommodate different Linux architectures:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.x86</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.mips</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.mpsl</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.arm4</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.arm5</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.arm6</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.arm7</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.ppc</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.m68k</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.sh4</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://163.123.143[.]126/bins/dark.86_64</span></li>
</ul>
<p>In the last step, the shell script downloader would block network connection from several ports including SSH, telnet and HTTP. It did so by modifying the device’s iptable rules, so that the victim wouldn’t be able to connect and recover the compromised device remotely, as depicted in Figure 1.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128225" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128225" style="width: 398px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128225" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-1.png" alt="Figure one is a screenshot of the modified iptable rules." width="398" height="400" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128225" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Iptable modification.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-128221-_yh4krhuzoae4"></a>Threat Group Analysis</h2>
<p>Unit 42 researchers conducted analysis on the downloaded botnet client samples and found two URLs hosting more shell script downloaders:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://2.56.59[.]215/i.sh</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://212.192.241[.]72/lolol.sh</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 2 is a diagram illustrating the campaign overview.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128227" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128227" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128227" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-2.png" alt="Figure 2 is a campaign overview diagram. It starts with the first IP address from April 10, 2023, and leads through the hosts, Mirai samples, the hosts, a shell script, and continues through the different downloaders." width="900" height="388" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128227" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Campaign overview diagram.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The shell script downloader from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2.56.59[.]215</span> would download botnet clients from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://2.56.59[.]215/bins/</span>. Those botnet client samples would contact a command and control (C2) server at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">195.133.40[.]141</span> where there were URLs in the malware samples that hosted two shell scripts:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://31.210.20[.]100/lolol[.]sh</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://212.192.241[.]72/lolol[.]sh</span></li>
</ul>
<p>The shell script downloader from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">212.192.241[.]72</span> would download botnet clients from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://212.192.241[.]87/bins/</span>, and those botnet client samples would contact the C2 domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dotheneedfull[.]club</span>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-128221-_1vwedkyxvan9"></a>Malware Analysis</h2>
<p>Based on behavior and patterns Unit 42 researchers observed during the analysis of the downloaded samples, we believe that they are a variant of the Mirai botnet called IZ1H9.</p>
<p>Discovered in August 2018, IZ1H9 is one of the most active Mirai variants. Just like the original Mirai, the IZ1H9 botnet client first checks the network portion of the infected device’s IP address. The client avoids execution for a list of IP blocks, including government networks, internet providers and large tech companies.</p>
<p>The botnet client makes its presence visible by printing the word “Darknet” to the console. The malware also contains a function that ensures the device is running only one instance of this malware. If a botnet process already exists, the botnet client will terminate the current process and start a new one, as depicted in Figure 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128229" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128229" style="width: 663px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128229" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-3.png" alt="Figure 3 is a screenshot demonstrating how the botnet client terminates a current process, and then starts a new one. Included in the code is “instance already exists, overriding current process.”" width="663" height="146" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128229" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. IZ1H9 ensures there is only a single instance of execution.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The botnet client also contains a list of process names belonging to other Mirai variants and other botnet malware families. The malware checks the running process names on the infected host to terminate them.</p>
<p>The IZ1H9 variant tries to connect to a hard-coded C2 address: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">193.47.61[.]75</span>, as shown in Figure 4.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128231" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128231" style="width: 333px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128231" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-4.png" alt="Figure 4 is a screenshot of the malware variant trying to connect to the hardcoded command and control (C2) IP address." width="333" height="123" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128231" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. IZ1H9 malware C2 address.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-128221-_dqef519hmlyy"></a>Botnet Client Configuration String Decryption</h3>
<p>For botnet client configuration strings, the IZ1H9 variant will first initialize an encrypted string table. It will then retrieve the encrypted strings through an index (as shown in Figures 5 and 6).</p>
<figure id="attachment_128233" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128233" style="width: 407px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128233" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-5.png" alt="Figure 5 is a screenshot of the encrypted string table. Highlighted in red is table_init()." width="407" height="457" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128233" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Initializing the encrypted string table.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_128235" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128235" style="width: 734px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128235" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-6.png" alt="Figure 6 is a screenshot of the malware variant retrieving strings. Highlighted within a red box is the code val = table retrieve val (84, 0). This is Mirai retrieving strings by index." width="734" height="259" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128235" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. IZ1H9 retrieving strings.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The IZ1H9 variant uses a table key during the string decryption process: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xBAADF00D</span>. For each encrypted character, the malware performs XOR decryption with the following bytewise operations:</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cipher_char ^ 0xBA ^ 0xAD ^ 0xF0 ^ 0x0D = plain_char</span></p>
<p>According to the logic behind XOR operation, the configuration string key equals to</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xBA ^ 0xAD ^ 0xF0 ^ 0x0D = 0xEA</span></p>
<h3><a id="post-128221-_q9t60pt9lkkn"></a>IZ1H9 Sample Spreading Through HTTP, SSH and Telnet Protocol</h3>
<p>For SSH and telnet channels, IZ1H9 inherits the most significant feature from the original Mirai source code: a data section with embedded default login credentials for scanner and brute-force purposes.</p>
<p>The original Mirai and IZ1H9 also both encrypt their login credentials with a 1 byte XOR key. The keys vary in different versions, but this variant uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x54</span>, as shown in Figure 7.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128237" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128237" style="width: 387px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128237" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-7.png" alt="Figure 6. IZ1H9 retrieving strings." width="387" height="115" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128237" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. IZ1H9 variant credentials XOR decryption.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This IZ1H9 variant initializes the table of nearly 100 pairs of telnet/SSH login credentials in the scanner function. It then spreads through brute forcing network devices’ weak username and password combinations.</p>
<p>For the HTTP channel, IZ1H9 uses four remote code execution vulnerabilities to get access to the vulnerable devices, and it executes the shellcode script downloader shown in Figure 8.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128239" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128239" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128239" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-8.png" alt="Figure 8 is a screenshot of the exploit scanner function. It shows the Zyxlel RCE, Blink, RCE, Netlog RCE, and the Tense RCE." width="900" height="633" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128239" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Exploit scanner function.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Notice that in the Tenda vulnerability exploit function, the payload downloads <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">tenda.sh</span> from the malware host server but executes <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">netlog.sh</span>, as shown in Figure 9. In this case, the exploit will not work.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128241" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128241" style="width: 805px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128241" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-9.png" alt="Figure 9 is a screenshot of the source code for Mirai. Highlighted in red boxes is tenda.sh, which downloads, and netlog.sh, which executes." width="805" height="224" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128241" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9: Malware executes wrong downloader.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The malware will initialize all DDoS attack functions before the botnet client establishes a connection with the C2 server. According to the Mirai source code, the malware developer will define the attack method and assign a command code to represent the attack method, as depicted in Figure 10.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128243" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128243" style="width: 541px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128243" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-10.png" alt="Figure 10 is a screenshot of the Mirai source code, with the definitions for all of the attack methods." width="541" height="252" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128243" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Mirai attack method definition.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In this IZ1H9 sample, the threat actor defines a set of attack methods, shown in Table 1.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 21.2115%;"><strong>Command </strong></td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 33.4578%;"><strong>Attack Method</strong></td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 76.4721%;"><strong>Description</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_tcpsyn</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">TCP SYN flooding attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">1</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_tcpack</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">TCP ACK flooding attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_tcpusyn</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">TCP URG-SYN flooding attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">3</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_tcpall</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">TCP DDoS with all options set</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">4</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_tcpfrag</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">TCP fragmentation attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">5</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_asyn</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">TCP SYN-ACK flooding attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">6</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_udpgame</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">UDP attack targets online gaming servers</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">7</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_udpplain</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">UDP flooding with fewer options</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">8</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_greip</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">GRE IP flooding attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">9</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_std</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">STD flooding attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">10</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_udpdns</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">DNS flooding attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">11</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_udpgeneric</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">UDP flooding attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">12</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_app_http</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">HTTP flooding attack</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.2115%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">13</span></td>
<td style="width: 33.4578%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">attack_method_dnsamp</span></td>
<td style="width: 76.4721%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">DNS amplification attack</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 8pt; color: #999999;"><em>Table 1. IZ1H9 attack method.</em></span></p>
<h2><a id="post-128221-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>IoT devices have always been a lucrative target for threat actors, and remote code execution attacks continue to be the most common and most concerning threats affecting IoT devices and linux servers. Exposed vulnerable devices could lead to serious threats.</p>
<p>The vulnerabilities used by this threat are less complex, but this does not decrease their impact, since they could still lead to remote code execution. Once the attacker gains control of a vulnerable device, they can include the newly compromised devices in their botnet. This allows them to conduct further attacks such as DDoS.</p>
<p>To combat this threat, it is highly recommended that patches and updates are applied when possible.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive protection from the vulnerabilities and malware discussed above through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li>Next Generation Firewall with a Threat Prevention security subscription can help block the attacks with Best Practices via Threat Prevention signatures: <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=93386" target="_blank" rel="noopener">93386</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=93718" target="_blank" rel="noopener">93718</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=93721" target="_blank" rel="noopener">93721</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=93722" target="_blank" rel="noopener">93722</a>.</li>
<li>Advanced Threat Prevention provides inline machine learning that can detect vulnerability exploits in real time.</li>
<li>WildFire can help stop the malware with static signature detections.</li>
<li>Advanced URL Filtering and DNS Security are able to block the C2 domain and malware-hosting URLs.</li>
<li>The Palo Alto Networks IoT Security platform can leverage network traffic information to identify the vendor, model and firmware version of a device, and it can identify specific devices that are vulnerable to particular CVEs.</li>
<li>In addition, IoT Security has inbuilt machine learning-based anomaly detection that can alert the customer if a device exhibits nontypical behavior such as the sudden appearance of traffic from a new source, an unusually high number of connections, or an inexplicable surge of certain attributes typically appearing in IoT application payloads.</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-128221-_v8176g40kstn"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<h3><a id="post-128221-_763h15eckspk"></a>Artifacts</h3>
<p><strong>Shell Script Downloader</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">692a5d099e37cd94923ea2b2014d79e6e613fb061a985069736dd3d55d4330c4</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e0b1c324298eeccd54ffc2ff48288ec51fbec44f5f82229537508785a9bda6de</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">931800d4f84bda7c0368c915dfd27721d63ed0ce6a9bc9f13e1417d4c2fe88f3</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64a350a33757f6631dc375632de191967ae59c876b4718a087e299bd54f23844</span></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Mirai Variant Sample</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">23190d722ba3fe97d859bd9b086ff33a14ae9aecfc8a2c3427623f93de3d3b14</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">00b151ff78a492b5eae0c8d3c769857f171f8424cf36c3b2505f7d7889109599</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">212b1af9fd1142d86b61956ac1198623f9017153153cfc20bfeab6a9fd44004a</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">38406b2effd9fc37ce41ee914fda798de9c9b0e239a0cc94b1464dc2a9984fe9</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">21185d9b7344edcd8d9c4af174e468c38cb3b061e6bd6bd64a4be9bd3fa27ff5</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">65a46cd29dad935d067a4289445d2efb2710d44d789bf1bf0efb29f94d20e531</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">06ef6c76e481d25aa09b3b15959d702be29c22d63bd35524766397e3d36d0d2e</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">7bfb02c563ae266e81ba94a745ea7017f12010d5491708d748296332f26f04f5</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1e29f364f502b313f01f28f1ae85bf27114fae5eede6550809fe5bca58f59174</span></li>
</ul>

<h2><a id="post-128221-_570cbe1pdhwx"></a>Additional Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/mirai-variant-v3g4/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mirai Variant V3G4 Targets IoT Devices</a> - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks</li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/mirai-variant-iot-vulnerabilities/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">New Mirai Variant Targeting Network Security Devices</a> - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks</li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/moobot-d-link-devices/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mirai Variant MooBot Targeting D-Link Devices</a> - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks</li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security-trends-aug-oct-2022/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Network Security Trends: August-October 2022</a> - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-128221-_tutgffqwaa7g"></a>Appendix</h2>
<p>Campaign-related vulnerability information is listed below:</p>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-27076" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>CVE-2023-27076</strong></a><strong>: Tenda G103 Command Injection Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>This malicious traffic was first detected as a part of the IZ1H9 campaign on April 10, 2023. The command injection vulnerability is due to the failure to sanitize the value of the language parameter in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cgi-bin/luci</span> interface of Tenda G103.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128245" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128245" style="width: 726px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128245" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-11.png" alt="Figure 11 is a screenshot of the Tenda G103 command injection vulnerability. It shows the cgi-bin." width="726" height="220" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128245" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. CVE-2023-27076 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-26801" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>CVE-2023-26801</strong></a><strong>: LB-Link Command Injection Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>We captured this exploit traffic on April 10, 2023. The exploit targets a command injection vulnerability in the LB-Link wireless router’s <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/goform/set_LimitClinet_cfg</span> component, which does not successfully sanitize the user input in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">time1</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">time2</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mac</span> parameters. This leads to arbitrary command execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128247" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128247" style="width: 657px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128247" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-12.png" alt="Figure 12 is a screenshot of the LB-Link command injection vulnerability, including the component that is exploited." width="657" height="114" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128247" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. CVE-2023-26801 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-26802" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>CVE-2023-26802</strong></a><strong>: DCN DCBI-Netlog-LAB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>The exploit was detected on April 10, 2023. The exploit works due to the Digital China Network DCBI-Netlog-LAB <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nsg_masq.cgi</span> component failing to adequately sanitize the user-supplied input data, which leads to remote command execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128249" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128249" style="width: 725px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128249" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-13.png" alt="Figure 13 is a screenshot of the DCN DCBI-Netlog-LAB Remote Code execution vulnerability. It shows the nsg_masq.cgi component in the first line of a screenshot." width="725" height="193" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128249" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. CVE-2023-26802 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://www.zyxel.com/global/en/support/security-advisories/zyxel-security-advisory-for-remote-code-execution-and-denial-of-service-vulnerabilities-of-cpe" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Zyxel Remote Code Execution Vulnerability</strong></a></p>
<p>We observed this exploit traffic on Dec. 16, 2022. The exploit targets the Zyxel router’s <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/bin/zhttpd/</span> component. If insufficient input validation is found, the attacker can exploit the vulnerability to launch a remote code execution attack.</p>
<figure id="attachment_128251" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-128251" style="width: 528px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-128251" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/word-image-128221-14.png" alt="Figure 14 is a screenshot of the Zyxel remote code execution vulnerability. Included is the line that is exploited in the router, /b/zhttpd/." width="528" height="75" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-128251" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Zyxel router exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Updated May 26, 2023, at 3:30 p.m. PT.</span></i></p>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 7 June, 2024 at 12:17 PM PDT</span>-->

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/10_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of Gatekeeper Bypass.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Gatekeeper Bypass: Uncovering Weaknesses in a macOS Security Mechanism:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/gatekeeper-bypass-macos/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Gatekeeper Bypass: Uncovering Weaknesses in a macOS Security Mechanism">

                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: CVE-2024-6387 OpenSSH RegreSSHion Vulnerability:High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-brief-cve-2024-6387-openssh/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: CVE-2024-6387 OpenSSH RegreSSHion Vulnerability">

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A digital illustration of a world map focused on Europe and parts of Asia, highlighted with glowing connections and nodes representing global connectivity." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Operation MidnightEclipse, Post-Exploitation Activity Related to CVE-2024-3400 (Updated May 20):High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/cve-2024-3400/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Operation MidnightEclipse, Post-Exploitation Activity Related to CVE-2024-3400 (Updated May 20)">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Brief: Operation MidnightEclipse, Post-Exploitation Activity Related to CVE-2024-3400 (Updated May 20)</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/midnighteclipse/" title="MidnightEclipse" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Operation MidnightEclipse, Post-Exploitation Activity Related to CVE-2024-3400 (Updated May 20):MidnightEclipse">MidnightEclipse</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cve-2024-3400/" title="CVE-2024-3400" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Operation MidnightEclipse, Post-Exploitation Activity Related to CVE-2024-3400 (Updated May 20):CVE-2024-3400">CVE-2024-3400</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/upstyle/" title="Upstyle" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Operation MidnightEclipse, Post-Exploitation Activity Related to CVE-2024-3400 (Updated May 20):Upstyle">Upstyle</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/cve-2024-3400/" title="Threat Brief: Operation MidnightEclipse, Post-Exploitation Activity Related to CVE-2024-3400 (Updated May 20)" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Operation MidnightEclipse, Post-Exploitation Activity Related to CVE-2024-3400 (Updated May 20):read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Close-up side profile of a Black woman wearing glasses, focused intently on something out of frame." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/05_Vulnerabilities_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094):High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-brief-xz-utils-cve-2024-3094/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094)">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094)</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cve-2024-3094/" title="CVE-2024-3094" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094):CVE-2024-3094">CVE-2024-3094</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/linux/" title="Linux" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094):Linux">Linux</a>

					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/xz-utils/" title="XZ Utils" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Threat Brief: Vulnerability in XZ Utils Data Compression Library Impacting Multiple Linux Distributions (CVE-2024-3094):XZ Utils">XZ Utils</a>

                <div class="card-content__link">

                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A cityscape with many highrises at night.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Exposing a New BOLA Vulnerability in Grafana:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/new-bola-vulnerability-grafana/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-iz1h9:related-resources:Exposing a New BOLA Vulnerability in Grafana">
